document.docTitle: Mysmenopsis choco Dupérré & Tapia 2020, new species
document.masterDocTitle: Megadiverse Ecuador: a review of Mysmenopsis (Araneae, Mysmenidae) of Ecuador, with the description of twenty-one new kleptoparasitic spider species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Megadiverse Ecuador: a review of Mysmenopsis (Araneae, Mysmenidae) of Ecuador, with the description of twenty-one new kleptoparasitic spider species

.

.
Etymology . The specific name is a noun in apposition taken from the Chocó region , one of the most biodiverse regions of the world.

Diagnosis. Males and females are distinguished by their abdominal pattern consisting of a longitudinal line of four white spots dorsally ( Figs 32, 33 ). Male most resemble
M. lasrocas
n. sp.
,
M. corazon
n. sp.
and
M. alvaroi
n. sp.
but can be distinguished as such: from
M. lasrocas
n. sp.
by the less pronounced paracymbium and curved embolus ( Figs 37, 38 ) much more pronounced paracymbium prolatero-dorsally and straight embolus in the latter ( Figs 57, 58 ); from
M. corazon
n. sp.
, and
M. alvaroi
n. sp.
by the blunt base of the embolus, with sharp edge in these two species ( Figs 104 , 112 ), dull in
M. choco
n. sp.
( Fig. 38 ). Females most resemble
M. lloa
n. sp.
but can be differentiated by the epigynum without sclerotized, darker band sub-apically ( Fig. 39 ) present in the latter species ( Fig. 84 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 31–35.
Mysmenopsis choco
n. sp. ,
31, Male and female habitus, dorsal view. 32, Male abdomen, posterior view. 33, Female abdomen, posterior view. 34, Male leg I, prolatero-dorsal view. 35, Female leg I, prolateral view. Scale bar: 31 – 33: 0.5mm; 34, 35: 0.1mm.

FIGURES 36–40.
Mysmenopsis choco
n. sp. ,
36, Male palp, retrolateral view. 37, Male palp, prolateral view (arrow points to cymbium excavation). 38, Embolus and apophysis retrolateral view. 39, Epigynum, ventral view. 40, Internal genitalia, dorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Natural history. Specimens were collected in
Linothele
sp. webs, the species inhabit the Andean region and was found in an evergreen foothill forest on the western side of the Andes (BsPn01) ( Guevara & Morales 2013 ) between
638– 735m
.
Mysmenopsis choco
n. sp.
is found in sympatry with
M. otokiki
n. sp.
and
M. awa
n. sp.
in Otokiki Reserve and in sympatry with
M. awa
n. sp.
in Sector Palo Amarillo.
